Technology Providers Bring Event-Based Trading to Brokers

1d ago//Tanya Chepkova
ethereumregulation
AI

Summary

TH

EN

The article features an interview with Dor Eligula of BridgeWise, an AI-powered research firm supporting brokers and exchanges. Eligula discusses potential growth in Asian markets, noting how local client behavior shapes demand, and elaborates on the integration of AI in investment research. He provides real-world examples of how automation complements human judgment to prevent errors and offers advice for retail investors on avoiding common AI pitfalls. Additionally, the text covers an interview with Brendan Callan, CEO of TRADU, who recently won a debate arguing against the current Prop Trading model. Callan critiques the industry for relying too heavily on fees, having loose risk controls, and creating confusion for retail traders.

Key Points

  • BridgeWise utilizes AI to provide research and analytics for brokers, seeing significant growth potential in Asian markets.
  • Effective AI integration in investment research requires balancing automation with human oversight to ensure accuracy.
  • TRADU CEO Brendan Callan argues that the current Prop Trading model is flawed due to fee dependency and risk management issues.
  • Local client behavior in Asia is driving specific demand for broker services and analytics.
  • Retail investors need practical guidance to utilize AI tools effectively without falling into common traps.

Article

Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Brendan Callan joined us fresh off the Summit‚Äôs most anticipated debate: ‚ÄúIs Prop Trading Good for the Industry?‚Äù Brendan argued against the motion ‚Äî and the audience voted him the winner. In this interview, Brendan explains the reasoning behind his position. He walks through the message he believes many firms avoid: that the current prop trading model is too dependent on fees, too loose on risk, and too confusing for retail audiences. We discuss why he thinks the model grew fast, why it may run into walls, and what he believes is needed for a cleaner, more responsible version of prop trading. This is Brendan at his frankest ‚Äî sharp, grounded, and very clear about what changes are overdue.
